node.title: C.D.C. Virus Tests Were Contaminated and Poorly Designed, Agency Says
node.alt: The C.D.C. released this test kit early in the pandemic, which was later found to be not only poorly designed, but contaminated.
node.description: An internal review documented two serious flaws in the test kits, which were distributed to public health laboratories in early 2020.
node.content: ["The faulty coronavirus testing kits developed by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in the early weeks of the pandemic were not only contaminated but had a basic design flaw, according to an internal review by the agency.", "Health officials had already acknowledged that the test kits were contaminated, but the internal report, whose findings were published in PLOS ONE on Wednesday, also documented a design error that caused false positives.", "The distribution of faulty test kits, at a time when no other tests were authorized, set back health officials\u2019 efforts to detect and track the virus.", "\u201cIt delayed the availability of more widespread testing,\u201d said Dr. Benjamin Pinsky, the director of clinical virology for Stanford Health Care. He added, \u201cI think it\u2019s important that they got to the bottom of what went wrong.\u201d", "In January 2020, the C.D.C. developed a polymerase chain reaction, or P.C.R., test for the virus. P.C.R. tests, which are performed in laboratories, can detect the virus at very low levels and have been considered the gold standard for diagnosing a coronavirus infection.", "Problems emerged soon after the C.D.C. had begun shipping its test kits out to public health laboratories in early February. Within days, many labs were reporting that the tests were generating inconclusive results.", "In mid-February, the agency acknowledged that the kits were flawed, and in April, officials at the U.S. Food and Drug Administration said that poor manufacturing practices had resulted in contamination of the test kits.", "The new paper presents the results of the C.D.C.\u2019s own internal investigation into the problems with the tests.", "The C.D.C.\u2019s test was designed to detect three distinct regions, or target sequences, of the virus\u2019s genetic material. The test kits contain a set of what are known as primers, which bind to and make copies of the target sequences, and probes, which produce a fluorescent signal when these copies are made, indicating that genetic material from the virus is present.", "The primers and probes need to be carefully designed so that they bind to the target sequences and not to each other. In this case, that did not happen. One of the probes in the kit sometimes bound to one of the primers, producing the fluorescent signal and generating a false positive.", "\u201cIt\u2019s something that should have been caught in the design phase,\u201d said Susan Butler-Wu, a clinical microbiologist at the Keck School of Medicine of the University of Southern California. \u201cThat\u2019s one thing that you check for.\u201d", "The investigation also confirmed that the test kits had been contaminated with synthetic fragments of the virus\u2019s genetic material. These synthetic sequences, which are often used to ensure that the tests are working properly, were manufactured at the same C.D.C. lab where the test kits were undergoing a quality analysis. It is \u201clikely\u201d that the test kits were contaminated there, the agency concluded.", "The contamination suggests that the agency violated standard manufacturing protocols, officials have said.", "The problems may also have been a sign of an agency in a rush, experts said.", "\u201cI\u2019m not entirely surprised that they ran into some glitches right out of the gate,\u201d said Dr. Emily Volk, president of the College of American Pathologists, who also praised the agency for its transparency. \u201cThey were asked to ramp up production in a way that I\u2019m not sure that they had ever been asked to before.\u201d", "The problems with the early tests prompted the C.D.C. to implement \u201ca more comprehensive and rigorous review process\u201d in developing a new test that can detect both the coronavirus and the flu, the authors reported. The new test was also piloted in three public health laboratories to ensure that it worked, they noted.", "\u201cSince the rollout of the initial Covid-19 test, C.D.C. has implemented corrective measures and remains dedicated to the highest quality laboratory science and safety,\u201d the agency said in a statement.", "The bigger lesson, Dr. Butler-Wu said, is that the responsibility for developing diagnostic tests should be distributed more widely during a public health emergency. Rather than relying on the C.D.C. to be the sole test developer, officials could also enlist clinical and commercial labs to create and deploy tests.", "\u201cIt\u2019s great that there\u2019s all these additional checks in place, but what are you going to do when there\u2019s a new emerging pathogen and we need to respond quickly?\u201d she said. \u201cI don\u2019t think that\u2019s a viable model for responding to a pandemic.\u201d"]
